recommendations: Consider Ventilation-Perfusion (V/Q) scan as a primary alternative to CTA for evaluating pulmonary embolism given the patient's severe renal dysfunction and hypotension.

If CT Pulmonary Angiography is deemed necessary, utilize a reduced contrast volume (e.g., 40-60 mL) with a slow injection rate (3-4 mL/s) and implement comprehensive pre- and post-hydration with isotonic saline.
Perform bedside transthoracic echocardiography to assess for right ventricular strain, which may support the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism and guide management without contrast.
Delay contrast-enhanced imaging until hyperkalemia and hypotension are corrected.
rationale: Severe CKD (eGFR 22 mL/min) and hypotension (MAP 57 mmHg) significantly increase the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) and hemodynamic compromise.
Hyperkalemia (5.8 mEq/L) poses a risk for cardiac arrhythmias and should be addressed prior to contrast administration.
Alternative imaging modalities like V/Q scans or bedside echocardiography can provide critical diagnostic information for suspected PE while minimizing renal and hemodynamic risks.
If CTA is performed, aggressive renal protection measures and reduced contrast load are essential to mitigate potential harm.

protocol_selection.name: CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE)
protocol_selection.description: CT angiography timed for pulmonary arterial phase (6–13 sec post-contrast) to evaluate pulmonary arteries for embolism.
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Weight-based; ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast (300 mg I/mL); follow ACR Manual.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Ensure contrast-to-eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min); if eGFR <30, consider non-contrast alternatives or weigh risks carefully.
